challengeName: True Detective - Companies Graph Visualization - AngularJS UI Prototype Challenge - Part 1
detailedRequirements:
Challenge Overview:
Welcome to the True Detective – Companies Graph Visualization - AngularJS UI Prototype Challenge - Part 1!

Note:
We will have a checkpoint deadline for this challenge to make sure we are all in the right direction, you can submit what have you done by then and get a prize of $100 if your work is in the right direction (Client will decide this not reviewers).

The main task of this challenge is to take the Angular seed project available at https://gitlab.com/jdrew/tcAngularSeed.git and using the https://github.com/anvaka/VivaGraphJS library build a prototype graph viewer.

Note all functionality in the graph should be handled as a plugin for VivaGraph!

Dummy data is being provided by client. Use the data supplied to the client along with https://github.com/rosiejs/rosie, https://github.com/marak/Faker.js/ and to help you build test data factories.

Challenge Requirements:
1. Get the basics of the prototype up and running:
Note at this point you do not need to have any styling implemented. This is just to make sure that the basic functionality of the prototype is handled, without getting distracted with styling. We will be focusing on implementing the basic functionality of the red boxes.

- Create an angular directive and wrapper for VivaGraphJS:
-- The directive should handle binding the data and updating the nodes. All data should be passed in through data attributes.
Note:
Take a look at https://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng/service/$compile and http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18939569/angularjs-passing-complex-data-to-directive to see how to do this using compile and data attributes.
-- Configuration should be handled by a provider.
Note:
Take a look at http://www.bennadel.com/blog/2788-creating-a-factory-provider-for-the-configuration-phase-in-angularjs.htm
- Using the test data display the graph of data:
Note:
Test data is available in a separate document.
-- All the data is linked through National Identity Number.
- Render a sidebar for information on the selected node. (Not in this challenge scope).

2. Basic styling of node types.
- The main node types so far are companies, people and link nodes. Other node types will feature in later tasks.
- Style the person nodes:
-- There are two node types (male and female).

-- There is 3 pieces of data in the unselected person node:
A- Their full name.
B- Their position.
C- Their picture. If their picture is not available, then you should display the default person icon for their gender in its place.
-- The background colours of the default logo should alternate through the bisnode colour palette.
-- A selected person node allows a user to display additional data on the user and their links to other data. The focus at the moment is on displaying the fact that it’s selected:
A- A selected node has icons displayed around the picture of the person.

- The description of the icons is handled by a legend in the top bar:

-- The legend bar should be its own directive. All data should be passed in through data attribute tags.
-- The styling for the legend needs to be changed from the picture:
A- The background of the legend bar should be transparent.
B- The icons should match the colour of the button shown but not the background colour. Please see design guide for details.

C- The legend should only be viewable when an element is selected that needs it.
- Company node:
-- The company node also has a selected and unselected state:
A-The icon for the company should display the company logo if available or the default image if not available. The background colours of the default logo should alternate through the bisnode colour palette.

B- The company node behaves very similar to the person node when selected. The legend should also be updated with icon information.

- The board member node should be added as a link node between board members (person node) and the company node as follows:


3. Reducing the size of the graph displayed will be done through expanding and collapsing nodes.
- We have a graph with a three companies in it.
-- If we start off with Neil Robert:

We start with Neil Roberts as our central node: The User details are presented in the sidebar. This can be hidden or expanded. His board colleagues and companies that he’s a board member of are displayed around his node.

-- We click on the company he is part of (Kastoria).

The board node is now displayed to show that he is part of the company board. We should be able to see the nodes of other companies that the board members are members of. They are not expanded.

-- Once we move more than three nodes away the screen will become cluttered with too many nodes. We will calculate the shortest path for each of the nodes in the graph and if the number of nodes in the shortest path (excluding link nodes, like the board node) exceeds 3 then we remove the node from the screen. This number should be configurable. NOTE: The reason we are limiting the linkages displayed to 3 degrees is that from here on there is a data linkage but in real life the likelihood is that there is actual link beyond this. For the reasoning behind this see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_degrees_of_separation
-- Once we move more than 5 nodes away we should group the intermediary company nodes together that are not linked by users on display (similar to how clustering of map pins works; see https://developers.google.com/maps/articles/toomanymarkers?hl=en).

4. Further relationships:
- There are other types of relationships that there can be between person nodes.

In this example we display a friendship relationship but it could just as easily be a works with relationship, or a family relationship, etc. These links follow the same rules as the company and person nodes.

5. Layout and animations:
- The layout of the nodes does not need to be as rigid as in the design but they should not be free flowing. All node names etc should be horizontal.
- Animations between expanding and collapsing nodes should be smooth. 

HTML/CSS/Javascript Requirements:
HTML5:
- Provide comments on the page elements to give clear explanation of the code usage. The goal is to help future developers understand the code.
- Please use clean INDENTATION for all HTML code so future developers can follow the code.
- All HTML code naming should not have any conflicts or errors.
- Use semantically correct tags - use H tags for headers, etc. Use strong and em tags instead of bold and italic tags.
- Your code must render properly in all browsers listed in the Browser Requirements section.  
- Validate your code - reviewers may accept minor validation errors, but please comment your reason for any validation errors. Use the validators listed in the scorecard.

CSS3:
- You're encouraged to use and take advantage of CSS3.
- Provide comments on the CSS code. We need CSS comments to give a clear explanation of the code usage. The goal is to help future developers understand the code.
- Please use clean INDENTATION for all CSS so developers can follow the code.
- All CSS naming should not have any conflicts.
- Validate your css - reviewers may accept minor validation errors, but please comment your reason for any validation errors. Use the validators listed in the scorecard.
- No inline CSS styles - all styles must be placed in an external stylesheet.
- Label all CSS, Javascript, or HTML hacks with explanations so others will understand.
- Use CSS to space out objects, not clear/transparent images (GIFs or PNGs) and use proper structural CSS to lay out your page. Only use table tags for tables of data/information and not for page layout.

Javascript:
- You must use AngularJS.  Use AngularJS best practices.
- 3rd party libraries can be leveraged in this challenge as long as they are free for enterprise use (no licensing fees), have no restrictions on distribution, selling and / or profiting from the use or sale of software including the library and do not require the source code of the software including the library to be made available to recipients of the software in binary or compiled form. Requirements to credit the library in the source code that uses it are fine (just be sure to follow any such requirements in your submission)
- Please document what libraries you have used and where in the prototype.

Web Browsers Requirements:
- IE11 - This is the primary browser the client is using. You must test your submission for all functionality and performance against this browser version.
- Firefox latest version.
- Safari latest version.
- Chrome latest version.

Supporting Documents:
- Storyboard and test data can be found in forums.
finalSubmissionGuidelines:
Submission Deliverables:
- A complete list of deliverables can be viewed in the UI Prototype Competitions Tutorial.

Final Submission:
- For each member, the final submission should be uploaded to the Online Review Tool.
